awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Biogeochemical drivers of interspecies electron transfer from iron reducers to methanogens
awd_abstract_narration:
Iron reduction and methanogenesis are two of the most common microbial reactions in nature. During iron reduction, microorganisms respire ferric iron, the form of iron in rust. During methanogenesis, microorganisms make methane, the primary component of natural gas and a potent greenhouse gas. Some iron reducers and methanogens, the microbes that drive the reactions, can cooperate with one another by sharing energy resources through interspecies electron transfer (IET). However, most predictive models assume that methanogens and iron reducers do not coexist, due to competition for energy sources, and only allow methane generation where ferric minerals have been depleted. Failure to account for both IET and competition may introduce error in process-based estimates of methane production. Moreover, environmental drivers of IET have not been identified, limiting the ability of models to predict how methane fluxes vary with environmental change. This study will create a new model for methanogenesis that links competitive and cooperative interactions. The model will improve the ability to predict methane generation and manage carbon budgets in natural and engineered systems including soils, aquifers, landfills, and wastewater treatment systems. The study will also provide training to undergraduate and graduate students and increase involvement of underrepresented groups in science through participation in the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation summer research program and summer outreach events for middle-school girls.

Research goals of this study are to: 1) identify environmental drivers that push interactions of methanogens and iron reducers between competition and IET, 2) determine how changes in interactions between methanogens and iron reducers affect methane generation, and 3) evaluate the coupled role of enzyme properties and environmental chemistry in determining the nature of interactions. To achieve these goals, the study will integrate the results of bioreactor experiments with dynamic enzyme modeling. The bioreactor experiments will examine how interactions and methane production vary with key biogeochemical factors, including pH, ferric iron source, and the availability of electron donors and ferrous iron. The modeling analysis will consider enzyme kinetics and reaction energetics to simulate reactions at a subcellular/enzymatic level, with experiment results providing a basis for validation. Both competition and syntrophy between methanogens and iron reducers will be possible in the experiments and simulations, allowing the study to resolve how interactions and methane generation evolve with environmental chemistry. Moreover, study findings will create a roadmap for evaluating the environmental significance of IET between iron reducers and methanogens by defining an environmental context for this interaction. In doing so, study results will provide the tools needed to advance our understanding of ecological underpinnings of the global methane cycle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT – NSF AWARD 1753436

Our project introduced two new models that simulate microbial interactions and their geochemical consequences. These new models improve the simulation of microbial metabolisms in natural environments (1) by simulating the kinetics of microbial consortia that have historically proven challenging to grow under typical laboratory culturing conditions, and (2) by bridging the gap in kinetics between enzymatic and metabolic reactions and the overall microbial processes in natural environments.

 

1. Organic matter degradation

We constructed a microbial reaction model for the anaerobic degradation of organic matter and applied the model to the peatlands of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, USA. This model accounts for the thermodynamics and kinetics of extracellular enzymes, fermentative microbes, and methanogens. We applied the model to investigate the temperature sensitivity inherent in organic matter decomposition and the biogeochemical implications of the Q10 coefficient. This parameter is the ratio of reaction rates at temperatures 10 °C apart, and has been widely employed to quantify temperature sensitivity of biogeochemical processes.

The results support a near-linear variation in the degradation rates of mesophilic microbial consortia across the temperature range of 5 to 30 °C. The results contrast with the exponential temperature dependence assumed by the Q10 approach. Consequently, the Q10 approach tends to underestimate greenhouse gas bioproduction rates by up to 40% within the temperature range used for Q10 determination, while exhibiting an overestimation beyond this range by several folds.

 

2. Anaerobic methane oxidation

 We constructed a metabolic model for Anaerobic Methane Oxidation (AOM). This model captured the pathway of reverse-methanogenesis and the canonical pathway of sulfate reduction. The model accounts for the kinetics and thermodynamics of biochemical reactions, operating on the assumption that member organisms within the consortia optimize their enzyme expression to achieve a dual objective of maintaining redox balance and attaining growth equilibrium.

We applied the model and simulated the kinetics of AOM and its dependency on methane and sulfate concentrations. The simulation results include the maximum rates of methane oxidation and sulfate reduction, as well as the half-saturation constants of methane and sulfate, which closely aligned with values determined through laboratory incubation experiments. We also explored the intriguing possibility of a 'super bug' capable of directly oxidizing methane by reducing sulfate. We showed that the ‘superbug’ is metabolically feasible, but ecologically impossible.

 

3. Broader Impacts 

We published four peer-reviewed papers, including an invited review article on biogeochemical kinetic modeling. The project strengthened the collaboration between the PI and Co-PIs at the two different institutions, and we co-taught a workshop on biogeochemical reaction modeling at Goldschmidt meeting. The project also provided training opportunities to an undergraduate and two Ph.D. students at the University of Oregon.

Modified by: Qusheng Jin
